headline.main: How to Shave $1 Trillion Out of Health Care

docs.abstract: Shaving $1 trillion out of health care costs would not reduce health outcomes, but would provide many other benefits, writes an economist.
docs.snippet: Shaving $1 trillion out of health care costs would not reduce health outcomes, but would provide many other benefits, writes an economist.

docs.lead_paragraph: White patients with breast cancer receive a diagnosis and treatment much faster.

headline.main: Why Black Women Die of Cancer
headline.print_headline: Why Black Women Die of Cancer

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Harold P Freeman, past president of American Cancer Society, explores why black women are more likely to die from breast cancer than their white counterparts; notes main reasons are barriers to early diagnosis and quality treatment; contends people should not die because of their race or financial situation; holds it is society's moral imperative to increase access to quality health care for the poor and less educated.
docs.snippet: White patients with breast cancer receive a diagnosis and treatment much faster.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lindsay Rosenthal of the Ms. Foundation for Women calls for proactive efforts to help girls in custody receive services.
docs.snippet: Lindsay Rosenthal of the Ms. Foundation for Women calls for proactive efforts to help girls in custody receive services.

docs.lead_paragraph: Eight Florida gay couples backed by a gay rights group have filed a lawsuit to force the state to recognize same-sex marriages from other states, saying their exclusion violates the right to equal protection under the U.S. Constitution.

headline.main: Gay Couples Sue Florida to Recognize Marriages in Other States
headline.print_headline: Gay Couples Sue Florida to Recognize Marriages in Other States

docs.snippet: Eight Florida gay couples backed by a gay rights group have filed a lawsuit to force the state to recognize same-sex marriages from other states, saying their exclusion violates the right to equal protection under the U.S. Constitution.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans attacked Obamacare with new ferocity but sometimes questionable veracity Thursday, energized by a campaign triumph in Florida that gave health care issues their first airing of the election year.

headline.main: GOP Hits Hard on Obamacare After House Election
headline.print_headline: GOP Hits Hard on Obamacare After House Election

docs.lead_paragraph: Renault was braced on Thursday for a strike at its in-house dealerships that may cause a wobble in the French carmaker's recovery from a long slump in auto demand.

headline.main: Renault Braced for French Dealership Strike
headline.print_headline: Renault Braced for French Dealership Strike

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans have a new calling card for the midterm elections, same as the old one.

headline.main: Analysis: Dispute on Obamacare Role in House Race

docs.lead_paragraph: Bama Covered is believed to be the only group doing enrollment for insurance under the Affordable Care Act that is made up solely of college students.

headline.main: In Alabama, College Students Take On Challenge of Health Insurance Sign-Up
headline.print_headline: In Alabama, College Students Take On Challenge of Health Insurance Sign-Up

docs.abstract: About 600 student volunteers from a dozen colleges in Alabama have been trained to help enroll people for insurance under Pres Obama's health care reform law; all-volunteer group is believed to be the only one doing enrollment entirely made up of college students, and founders hope if they can succeed in the red state, their effort will be replicable across the country.
docs.snippet: Bama Covered is believed to be the only group doing enrollment for insurance under the Affordable Care Act that is made up solely of college students.

docs.lead_paragraph: A type of Medicare in which private insurers provide coverage remains attractive to Americans, but proposed reductions in government payments may change the benefits offered.

headline.main: Medicare Changes Prompt Enrollees to Reconsider Plans
headline.print_headline: Medicare Changes Prompt Enrollees to Reconsider Plans

docs.abstract: Changes to payments made by the federal government to Medicare Advantage insurers contained within the health care reform law have set some Medicare Advantage subscribers scrambling.
docs.snippet: A type of Medicare in which private insurers provide coverage remains attractive to Americans, but proposed reductions in government payments may change the benefits offered.
